conclusion: To determine if objects A and B have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \), we need to analyze their velocity-time graphs.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, which can be determined from the slope of the velocity-time graph.
Object A: The graph shows a curve that starts at \( v_0 \) and decreases over time.
Object B: The graph shows a straight line that starts at \( v_0 \) and decreases linearly over time.

premise: The slope of the graph at any point represents the acceleration at that point.
conclusion: For Object A, the slope of the curve at \( t_1 \) is the tangent to the curve at that point.

premise: The slope of the graph at any point represents the acceleration at that point.
conclusion: For Object B, the slope of the straight line is constant and can be calculated as the change in velocity divided by the change in time.

premise: For Object A, the slope at \( t_1 \) is the tangent to the curve at \( t_1 \). This slope is not constant and depends on the curvature of the graph.
conclusion: The slope of Object A at \( t_1 \) is not constant.

premise: For Object B, the slope is constant and can be calculated as: \[ \text{Slope of Object B} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{v_0 - 0}{t_4 - 0} = \frac{v_0}{t_4} \]
conclusion: The slope of Object B is constant and equal to \( \frac{v_0}{t_4} \).

premise: The slope of Object A at \( t_1 \) is not equal to the slope of Object B at \( t_1 \) because Object A's graph is a curve, and its slope changes over time, while Object B's graph is a straight line with a constant slope.
conclusion: The two objects do not have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \).
